abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Puttalam Housing Project
            (PHP) for Sri Lanka were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory; and the
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: implementation arrangements. The
            implementation arrangements with a field-based project unit
            in Puttalam helped to address the needs of the Internally
            Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Puttalam in a timely manner.
            However, the project demonstrated that effective
            implementation through this model requires a well
            capacitated project unit coupled with effective coordination
            at the center. Planning for integrated investments, housing,
            water, sanitation, and roads relate closely to each other
            and thus, any interventions that provide these services in a
            package require integrated planning covering technical
            design aspects, staffing, and sequencing of implementation.
            Owner-driven construction, this ICR recognizes the
            challenges that were faced by the home-owners in undertaking
            housing construction as per schedule, but the experience
            seemed to have been appreciated by the owners. The provision
            of cash grants ensured beneficiary participation in the
            construction of their houses, facilitated choice in design
            and use of construction materials, and reduced the cost of
            construction. Technical officers supervised construction
            while a technical audit independently monitored compliance
            with engineering standards. Job training program/skills
            development is one of the important activities of the PHP
            was to create required construction skills among the
            Puttalam IDPs. The skills training program was designed to
            meet the demand for skilled and semi-skilled masons and
            carpenters in project areas. Community involvement in water
            supply investments is one of the institutional mechanisms
            for social integration that worked well under the project
            was the formation of Community Based Organization (CBOs) for
            managing water supply schemes.
